title: Depth of Field and Astigmatism in Rainbow Holography
description: Analyze the effects of depth of field and astigmatism on image clarity in a rainbow hologram.
insight: Astigmatism arises because of the differing curvatures of horizontal and vertical wavefronts, limiting the hologram's depth of field.
question_text:
In a white-light rainbow holographic setup, a hologram is viewed from a distance of $$D_{view} = 500 \, mm$$. The acceptable astigmatism limit is set to $$0.25 \, diopters$$. Calculate the allowable depth of field (both in front of and behind the viewer at 500 mm) before astigmatism-induced blur becomes significant.

Use the relationships:
$$A_1 = \frac{1}{D_{view}} - \frac{1}{D_{front}}$$ and $$A_2 = \frac{1}{D_{back}} - \frac{1}{D_{view}}$$,
where $$A_1$$ and $$A_2$$ correspond to the allowable astigmatism limits.

solution.final_answer: Allowable depth of field: 71 mm in front and 56 mm behind the veiwer (at 500 mm).

insight: Astigmatism results from differences in horizontal and vertical focus, creating a limited depth of field and reducing image clarity.
